Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Sample Design for Alaska Natives in Anchorage
Award.AbstractNarration:
This EAGER research develops a viable sampling methodology and survey protocol, including the working partnerships, software, hardware, and key personnel, to implement a representative survey of Alaska Native households in Anchorage. This lays the foundation for several follow-on survey research projects, in particular a social ties research proposal, as well as rural-urban migration research, research on urban participation in subsistence harvest and sharing, and social indicators research.

The problem is that no sample frame of Alaska Natives in Anchorage exists. Furthermore, with only 7.7% of the Anchorage population Alaska Native, a standard random household sample is not a cost effective method to locate them. The research pilot tests two complementary methodologies: a random sample of the census tracts and blocks with the greatest concentrations of Alaska Natives, and a quota sample generated through convenience and snowball sampling techniques. In addition to estimating sampling error, key questions in the pilot data are compared to American Community Survey data to assess potential bias. The pilot survey also develops a new survey technology and protocol using hand-held computers; measures the effects of incentives on survey response rates; generates preliminary estimates of ANCSA regional affiliations and migration status for use in future survey research designs; and pre-tests questions for the social ties research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sampling Methods for Alaska Natives Living in Anchorage

This project was funded through EAGER—Early-concept Grants for Exploratory Research.

In the winter of 2013 we tested two methods: a random-cluster sample of 2010 Census tracts and blocks with higher percentages of Alaska Native residents, and a quota sample generated through a snowball (word of mouth) technique. We used these methods hoping to select Alaska Natives in a manner that the results would represent all Alaska Natives living in Anchorage, Alaska.  This method would be more efficient and less expensive than the more commonly used random and probability designs. To accomplish this we conducted a household survey using the random-cluster and quota methods  to determine the cost of each method and to see how well each represented the population.


The random-cluster is a technique where census blocks are selected and all interviews are with people who live within the selected blocks. The quota sample comes from a snowball series of referrals and from those referrals participants are selected to be interviewed based on the quota, which is a set of predetermined characteristics such as age, sex, and location. Through statistical tests we determined that the interviews did not produce representative results. There can be several reasons for this lack of representativeness. The sample size may have been too small. Another reason may be that respondents in the quota sample referred respondents similar to themselves. For example, examining marital status, "never married" respondents formed a much larger proportion in the quota sample than both the random cluster sample and the census data. Comparing data on educational attainment, the quota sample had a much higher proportion of respondents who stated they were high school graduates and much smaller proportion of those with less than a high school diploma than expected. 


The cost per completed interview was $261 for the random-cluster sample and $138 for the quota sample. This includes training and mileage, but not supervision or analyses. The cost for the random sample interviews was expected to be lower because they were drawn from blocks with higher percentages of Alaska Native residents, while conversely the cost for the quota interviews were expected to be higher because the densest blocks were excluded. In addition, households in the quota sample were widely dispersed leading to expectations of higher costs in both mileage and interviewer time.


To measure the effect of an incentive on respondents’ willingness to answer additional questions we offered an incentive of $20.00. About two-thirds of the way into the questionnaire the computer generated a random number. If the number was even, the respondent received the incentive.  All respondents were told at this point whether they would receive the gift card and were asked if they wished to continue and answer more questions. Of those who received the incentive, 98% were willing to answer additional questions. Among those who did not receive the incentive, 31% were willing to answer additional questions. Additionally, interviewers reported feeling that the possibility of receiving the gift card improved willingness to participate at the start. Thus, confirming our personal past experience and that widely reported in literature: the incentive increased the likelihood of response and thus, the response rate.
